aicpa-topic.title: Floor Brokerage, Exchange Fee, and Clearance Expenses

body.p: 6.119 Floor brokerage. Broker-dealers often use other brokers to execute trades on their behalf. The trading broker-dealer becomes a customer of the executing broker-dealer and pays a floor brokerage fee. Such fees are paid periodically either directly to the executing broker-dealer or through a clearinghouse.

6.120 Exchange fees. Exchange fees are charged by securities exchanges and clearing houses for the privilege of trading securities listed on that exchange. Some fees vary with the related volume, whereas others are fixed. For transaction charges, each broker-dealer submits a monthly report of net commissions earned on transactions executed on the exchange. This report is used for the self-determination of the exchange fee. Floor brokerage and exchange fees generally vary proportionally with the volume of trades executed by the broker-dealer on the exchange.

6.121 Clearance expenses. Introducing broker-dealers may employ a securities clearing firm to clear and settle trades with other parties or with an external clearing corporation. The clearing firm will charge clearance expenses to the broker-dealer for performing these services.
